page.title: 02GEOLOGY OF POTT SHRIGLEY
page.content: Underlying the area are the Pennine sandstones known as gritstone. They are interspersed with coal bearing shale bands which often outcrop on the surface due to the tilted strata and several minor faults. There are many small coal pits, now worked out and capped for safety by the National Coal Board. Mining was an important local industry in the last century. Numerous stone buildings and walls testify to the ease of quarrying rock which is so close to the surface and one large quarry is still working. The Red Rock Fault crosses Adlington in a north/south direction near the western boundary of the block.Here the shales dip sharply below pebble beds overlaid with clay and sand, which produce a much softer landscape than the thinner soils and more broken ground of the hills to the east.
